threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This is a place to discuss topics about visual or graphic design. Requests for photoshopping or free work go on /wsr/ - Worksafe Requests or /r/ - Adult Requests as appropriate.

#/gd/ @ irc.rizon.net
#4chan-gd @ irc.freenode.net
http://graphicdesign.wikia.com/

>What literature should I read to get into graphic design?
The sidebar on the /gd/ wiki has plenty of book reccomendations.

>What programs do I need to get started?
-Vector
Adobe Illustrator
Corel Draw
Inkskape

-Bitmap
Adobe Photoshop
Gimp

-3d
Blender
Cinema4d

>Which program is the best for X?
It's usually subjective if you pick a program in each of the right categories above. Use vector programs if your making a logo/icon/illustraton, use bitmap programs if you're messing with a photo or stock image. Gimp, Inkskape, and Blender are free alternatives and have the same function as the paid programs but the paid programs tend to be used more in a professional enviroment.

>What font is used in this image?
Try these sites before posting a tread asking for fonts:
http://whatthefont.com/
http://www.identifont.com/identify.html

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>Can somebody photoshop X? Can somebody make me a logo?
All requests for photoshopping belong on /wsr/ - Worksafe Requests or /r/ - Adult Requests. /gd/ doesn't take requests or do free or even paid work sometimes. However, if you're new at something, asking "HOW can I X?" rather than "CAN YOU make X?" will give you better results.

>Can I post some of my work for critique?
There is usally a critique/What-Are-You-Working-On thread, and that is where work for critique go.

>Can somebody find [font]?
http://www.mediafire.com/download/027xjs3ujvyqxmd/Fonts.zip
also check out your local torrent site or the font-share thread.
Remember to share and not just take. Also remember that using liscensed fonts in commercial works is a bad idea.

>Where can I find inspiration?
http://www.behance.net/
http://dribbble.com/
http://graphicdesign.wikia.com/wiki/Inspiration

>>438072
The rule of thumb for a book title, is the "glance" rule - it should be legible if glanced at on a shelf in a book store. Or, you can go in the opposite direction, and make the art what catches the eye. Yours is currently that. So, decide what you want to do.
I would a cleaner font, to offset the splash of confusion of the art - you're trying to get way too much information across with the art, it's jumbled and has it's own composition errors and style issues (why is everything the same line width?), but the title blurs into the art because it's too small, and too similar. You want contrast between the title, and the art. Decide which one is more important.

The font you're using is also really fucking hard to read, and the yellow drop shadow is ugly. You're trying too hard with this cover, across the board.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
What's the best way to achieve this classic style of diagram? Most of these were made before photoshop, or made with old computer programs, I assume.

How do you most easily get this look? It's simple and subtle, but there is a definite look to it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437873
transfer lettering was common, in places like print shops and newspapers and other publishers that could afford it there was also phototypesetting that could output copy on film or paper tapes that could be pasted up to make stuff like OPs pic.
Right before desktop system scalable type and printers caught up and were still just glorified typewriters, picrel was total amazeballs.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438033
Yep. Every medium size town and up had local service bureaus that would produce type for you, and would convert B&W photos and art into a halftone screen. And, a lot of linework was done with mechanical pens like Rapidographs, instead of letraset. (Letraset was pricey back then) Everything was done on illustration board or layout paper. Desktop publishing wiped out a huge field of jobs of people who did layout for a living, and the companies who supported it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438086
You used to be able to buy sheets of pre-waxed layout paper with non repro blue grid lines, and if you were hot shit you had pic related and a power eraser.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438091
anyone learning the ink on mylar has a power eraser. shit aint gone.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438091
One of the first places I worked, an ad agency, still had a couple of these. I learned a lot about old school design at those places, like how a kneaded blue eraser was called a mouse. They had drawers and boxes full of old drafting tools, like ink compassed and every kind of plastic triangle you could imagine. I grabbed some when they started clearing a bunch of it out. They had a bunch of airbrushing stuff, they used to do image editing on film with them, and used them for gradations and all that - with rolls and rolls of acetate and rubylith for mechanical seperations.

threads.sub: Should i drop out graphic design collegue?
threads.com: I started going in a meme university months ago and i thinks it's utter shit, because we hardly ever do things related to the degree and lose so much time that i could use more efficiently if i could be self taught instead. Also, i plan on living from art (self taught) but was pressured by my mother to go an university and chose the graphic design degree, not only because it's a discipline that im genuinely interested but also the thing that i could get the most of. I think that i could save so much money and time if i could drop out and learn all graphic design theory by myself, but i keep hearing that a degree is absolutely necessary to get jobs and be succesful, is that true?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Well, graphic design is a pretty oversaturated field. A degree does set you apart from others, but I don't think it should be an art degree. I would say that business or some form of marketing / advertising degree would be much more valuable for you long term. Anything that you can think of that's complementary, or graphic design is complementary of. Maybe even computer science, computer programming. Graphic design is a very saturated field. You need something that's going to set you apart and make you more valuable to have around than some piece of eye candy, considering every other Tinder slut is a graphic designer.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438053
One, learn how to spell college, you're in college.
Two, graphic design is a huge field. Which part are you going to try and work in?
Three, graphic design is one of the few fields where your portfolio and abilities can still get you hired without a degree, but a degree helps, if you want to rise in the industry to managment, and most art directors and creative directors get degrees in communications and marketing, on top of GD.
Fourth, "graphic design theory" is a bit of bullshit. It's not theory, it's working practices and the tools, with some theory like color theory and such. You can teach yourself, but it's the frameworks you won't learn on your own, or practices, like what the actual production pipeline you'll expected to be part of. it used to be you could get a night time part time gig and learn on the job for shit pay at an ad agency to learn the ropes, but those spots are highly coveted by tons of graduates from design schools who can't get a job. So what makes you more hireable than them, especially since they can walk in, and get the job done with a minimum of questions and mistakes?
I've worked in jobs where I had to help hire more designers. The number one thing we looked at was the portfolio, and if they could get the job done, and we could tell very quickly in the interview if they were clueless how to do that.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>438097
>How saturated is the market?
Very. GD degrees are very popular, and programs in colleges very full. There's a lot of people on the street looking for a job with a mediocre design degree and portfolio, and it seems like that's been true since the rise of desktop publishing.
The key with any creative positions is your brain. You're either good at technical details, like pre-press and production design, when you build up a layout to print properly and conform to styles and such, or you're good at ideas, pikcing colors, building the styles production designers follow, etc. That kind of job is typically not entry level.
>How do you know when they could get the job done?
Asking them questions. Those jobs were in print production, so we could ask them about experience with things like CMYK, color correction, pre-flighting jobs for the press, how to set up bleeds and knock outs, things like that. There are a lot of nuts and bolts parts of print production they don't teach in school, and it's easy to see when someone is in over their head - but we'd also look for people who want to learn it. We'd get a ;lot of prima donna designers who had the attitude of "That's pre-press's problem, not mine" - and we saw that as 'This bitch is gonna cost us thousands in pre-press fees".
These days, you're probably going to be looking at web based design, so it will be different issues.

last_replies.com: hey guys, how do i color switch the palette of a camouflage pattern? is there a way to pick all of a color range and switch that?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437679
yes you can select by color.
select > color range (or sumin)

but depending on your project that might actually be a difficult route to take.

other possibilities (if your input allows for it) would be gradient maps with multiple color steps, color fill layers set to color blend mode and masked by using 'blend if' in the layer properties and of course the good'ol hue/saturation slider (which will likely look like shit).
of course it could also be a combination of all of these.

I personally avoid rasterized alpha masks at all costs and try using procedual masking like blend if whenever possible.

Why is /gd/ so specific to the fairly niche field of graphic design when there's so many other design fields with no place to discuss them on 4chan?

I feel like it'd make sense to make /gd/ the de-facto place for those sort of things in the same way /n/ includes urban planning, /co/ includes live action comic adaptations, and /k/ includes military vehicles.
Graphic design really doesn't feel like an expansive enough topic to really *need* a board all to itself, and it's almost /po/ levels of dead. I don't think opening it to other fields of design would degrade board quality or anything.

yeah, funny.
I think it is very important to activate your conscious brain while designing. In reality this arguably presents itself by creating with a search for intent, Id say.
BUT.
If you fall for the trap of believing that every element of a design you do MUST ALWAYS be intentional, you are kinda blocking your more emotional/unconscious/musing (but random) side of your creative journey.
In the end you will find a balance of these that works for you and in your cases. and honestly looking at the different artists there are, you could end up on many places between the extremes and be successful with it.

nevertheless. one thing will stay the same.
the design (should be but) must not be so much done with intent, as it has to be suggesting intent to the viewer.

Its a fine line. A distinction, that we could probably spend some time debating on (and maybe even trash afterwards), but for now just consider that there are good designs of people who never really consciously reasoned why they are doing what they are doing, but who still manage to create pieces which make 'the viewer' feel properly guided and taken care of.

take the iridescent sticker thing as an example.
it kinda looks like a random asset you slapped on there.
it doesnt really match the rest and you made it so tiny it looks as if you were uncertain even putting it on.
show intent and make it bigger!

last_replies.com:
>>436732
I mean, overall my art director is very helpful, but she was hired 6 months after I was and I felt her method of doing things kinda threw a wrench in our workflow.

Usually a project manager would assign a project. I’d create a proof with some designs, and the project manager would send the proof to the client and then return with their feedback. We usually upload a proof in a work management site where anyone can easily leave comments.

With this art director, she’ll ask for the tiniest revisions like “make this word 25% smaller”, or “move this block down a tiny bit”.

For one project, the client required a high-res photo of one of the hotel properties to be used as a hero image. All we needed to do was provide a photo from the company’s photo repository. Even after uploading the photo in the proof, the art director asked if I could “make the photo a bit brighter”.

The photo was of a bright beautiful beach scene already heavy edited. Since we were already at deadline, I felt this was an unnecessary change that would end up adding 15-30 minutes of time, just uploading the damn thing. I pushed back and said “this photo already seems bright enough already and we’re close to deadline. Let’s just submit what we have, and if the client feels it should he brighter, I’ll make the change”. She agreed, we sent it over, and what do you know? The client just liked the photo as is.

While I feel this art director is helpful, I feel she’s requesting the smallest of changes. Which would be fine if we were in the beginning stages, but she’ll ask for “a few more tiny revisions from me :)” when we’re at or past deadline.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

Different anon here, but I recall nitpick details people gave me a hard time about, and I finally just had them sit down with me and just tell me exactly as they invisioned it. Literally pixel by pixel, I just let them say whatever came to mind, hardly offered any insight, and they hardly asked for it. The project was painful to do, and other clients wanted to do it this way also while trying to short my hours. I since left the field and am now in manufacturing. I didn't have the right conditions to flourish in the arts and sciences, but oh well, "World needs ditch diggers, too." - Caddyshack

Later, I learned it was not the art they wanted, but what the art facilitated: a feeling of value.

One day at a time, and you will be on track to lead these kinds of projects in bigger capacities. Good things are coming your way.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>436754
That's the same clipart I used to make my example...it's very traditional and flat and just...there.
If a "modern" take is really the goal it's going to take something fairly radical to shake off that generic look.
I did it with forcing the perspective and making it an oval, the leaves at the top got compressed and would need more work on a real graphic but that effect does simplify how it reads because it still suggests the laurel but without large separate leaves...it's more impressionistic and less literal.
The oval shape also adds a twist on the generic one and i think is more streamlined without being too far out.
Not saying this is *the* solution, just offering ideas on getting away from the cliche one while still keeping the essence of it that makes it recognizable as an award seal.

As for the AD, it really sounds like someone not very sure of themselves trying to assert their place but not confident enough to really take charge and direct bold moves....hence a bunch of tiny tweaks. It's a good sign that you pushed back and she was reasonable about it, the end result was a happy client so use that to guide her in the future and you can probably minimize a lot of that kind of change for changes sake directive.
Learning how to read people and assert yourself with superiorsxand clients is a huge part of this kind of work, it takes diplomacy and confidence on your part as well. It's not always easy to blend the two and certain people and situations will require a different mix. It's sales in some respect, and sales tactics can help- you need to reassure people that you're there to help them get their needs met, want what's best for them, and you need to steer them towards resolutions by eliminating barriers they put up to accepting what you are selling.
1/2

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>436774
2/2
That process might need to happen over an entire concept but it might also be necessary over a single leaf on a cheesy Clipart laurel branch. If you are passionate about what you feel is important and willing to compromise and accept constructive criticism you'll be fine and rather than being seen as ornery your willingness to push back will make you less of a target for nitpicking and hopefully will cause people choosing respect and value your willingness to fight for what you think is the best product.
Managers and clients may think they want a yes man or get mad when they get told no, but especially in this kind of field you really dont want a yes man, you want all contingencies addressed before you're in too deep and that's a huge part of what any design work involves.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Institutional logos or whatever this is called. New to /gd/ and planning to make a bunch of these for mundane stuff as practice. What makes these logos appealing and what doesn't? Pls post inpos as well if you have them

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437592
Most of those would be most accurately described as seals, which are identifiers like logos but more about official formal authentication in the manner of old timey wax seals and signets as opposed to advertising, although they can certainly be used for the latter...the LaSalle one even mimics the squeeze out of wax on its border like a wax seal does.
They also differ from logos in that traditionally they were made more complex to make them harder to fake when wax seals were used as security to confirm that documents, letters, etc hadn't been tampered with. Logos are all about instant recognition without the need to inspect them carefully, seals are supposed to be looked at closely taking time to verify that they're real and intact.
That detail and complexity can work against a logo, and the traditional lettering on an arc can be a real chore to read...but if that's the look you want because it's expected (like for a university or government agency) or it's going to be used as an actual seal, then quick readability is secondary and fine details add to the effect.
Part of that is that fine detail takes time and skill to print, and that's another way to weed out fakes...it costs more but it's a security measure. That's why paper money and stamps and similar valuable certificates are designed with tons of fine detail.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437610
Forgot to add, for inspiration look at state and corporate seals, both are still used to authenticate documents through embossing which is hard to fake accurately...schools do it with diplomas too, which is part of why they still stick with those traditional styles.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>436951
What kind of graphic design? Web? You don't need a lot of computer. Publishing? You need more. 3D? Even more. High end photo editing and color correction? The most computer you can buy. Large document publishing like catalongs? Even more.

For general Creative Suite tasks, 16 gigs of ram, a GPU newer than 5 years (5 year old Mac would be fine, M1/M2 are fine), and plenty of disk space, not just for installing the Suite, but you should have a decent sized, dedicated swap partition JUST for Adobe on your boot or secondary drive, and as fast as possible. I have a 10gig dedicated partion on an M1, and a 20gig partition on a second internal ssd on my windows laptop. Swap is important, it's one of THE bottlenecks for gd apps - PS stores your current working file, it's save states and history, and everything else while the file is open on the scratch disk. Even back in the HDD days, you'd want a fast drive for it, and not the same HDD as the system, to keep it thrashing around trying to maintain it, and the system caches.

I'll stop there, because if there's one thing that's true on /gd, is that most of you don't really know what graphic design is, how huge a field it is, and overlaps with 3d design and video. Or think that graphic design is painting.

Well, I live in Sweden, so I'm not exactly in the third world... yet. But I did live in Thailand for about 4 years and worked remote, doing programming and GD.

Any kind of remote work is really good if you live in a poor country where the average salary is extremely low. Basically doing even a small project for an american or european company could net you 2-5k eur/usd easily for a weeks or a few weeks work, which is enough to sustain you in a poor country for probably a few months. Obviously that also depends on your country and what laws/taxes they have imposed for income from remote international work. Some countries tax nothing, while others tax heavily.

So yea, it's probably not the worst thing you could do to learn GD or programming, but you'll have a ton of competition from India and other similar "developing nations". Just be aware that you'll need to work harder on marketing your services and networking to land clients than the actual projects.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>437300
That example's particular layout style with a bold, simple tag line in plain text and tons of unused space was one of a gazillion variations on the VW print ad concept that turned that industry on its ear beginning in the late 50's. It began as something of a poke in the eye towards the rigid conventions of the day about what ads like that "should" look and read like, was wildly successful and embraced by consumers as hip and irreverent and perfectly in tune with the product ...but after everyonecand their dog jumped on that bandwagon that look eventually became the very thing it was originally an antidote to: a formulaic convention that was literally everywhere by the mid 70's. Its still around and as you say still used to convey a "hip" sensibility...but the novel aspect of it is long gone and its vibe is more of a retro/nostalgia hip than a fresh and forward thinking hip, and elicits a sense of reverence rather than irreverence.

"Each Volkswagen ad was designed to be so complete that it could stand alone as a viable advertisement, even without addressing all aspects of the automobile.

Taken as a sign of the campaign's runaway success, research by the Starch Company showed that these Volkswagen advertisements had higher reader scores than editorial pieces in many publications, noting that Volkswagen advertisements often didn't even include a slogan and had a very subdued logo. (Krone didn't believe in logos, and there is some evidence that their inclusion followed a disagreement with the client.) "

https://www.vintag.es/2017/03/23-remarkable-volkswagen-ads-of-1960s.html?m=1

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I graduated a few years ago and something I’ve realized is that you can do whatever you want with a degree in graphic design. I would aim for an agency gig where you’ll be in the position of using your skills and communicating with vendors and clients and exposing yourself to all the parts of design that aren’t about design, moreso the business and cadence of managing a project.

But you can start a company selling dog treats if you wanted, or work as a copywriter and do nothing visually, or become a UX consultant.

A lot of people would kill to have the eyes of a designer, so you’re in a very unique space to start developing the language you use to communicate what you do. Get used to speaking about stuff like brand voice, case studies, or whatever you want. Maybe focus less on what you do on a technical level and more about where you see you and your eye for design within a company or organization you care about.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Gainesville, Florida
A Florida town wanted to become “a more competitive place for new businesses and talent.” Here’s how that went:

How do you make a city “citizen-centered”? IDEO’s report prescribes nine changes for Gainesville. Early in the list is rebranding: adopt a new logo, tagline, and visual style. Another is to create a “Department of Doing,” an office to help people start or grow businesses in Gainesville. Finally, the report says, the city should become more design-minded. It should train city employees in “design thinking”: the use of design methods to solve problems. It should replace City Commission subcommittees with design-thinking workshops and frame policy questions as design questions.

It went badly. IDEO completely missed the realities for most residents.

Gainesville is among the poorest cities in America, and one of the least racially equitable in the distribution of income and resources. Black residents, who make up 22 percent of the city population, live largely in East Gainesville, where residents report severely limited grocery options, inadequate transportation, and poor street lighting. The median household income for Black residents of Gainesville’s county is $26,561 — just over 50 percent of the median household income for non-Hispanic whites. High school graduation rates for Black residents of the county are 18 percent lower than those of white residents. Black residents are almost 2.5 times as likely as white residents to be unemployed.

A new logo, tagline, and website misses the mark. A “Department of Doing,” whatever that is, and running more design thinking workshops (ka-ching!) miss the mark. Design thinking couldn’t understand, empathize with, or solve the “wicked problems” of poverty and systemic racism.

>>436373
How to make a stylish UI:
Some of my personal favorites are diegetic, if you need to make the player flip though menu's at least make them interesting.

Some general rules of thumb are to take your games stylistic choices and blend them into your menu's. Then add some extra movement to them. Persona 5's style follows a no rules street style so blending jagged shapes and vibrant colors into menu designs really helps bring life to what would otherwise just be a blank canvas. Avoid clutter by cutting things down to their most basic elements. If a single page could take the place of an entire sub folder of confusing pages then simplify.

If you cant actively pull off an action in menu within 1 minute then you may need to rethink your layout. Try drawing out your folders and make things more concise.
